docs.lead_paragraph: Accountable care organizations, a new kind of health care practice, are gaining momentum in part because of the Affordable Care Act signed into law two years ago.

headline.seo: With Small-Picture Approach, A.C.O.’s Gain in Health Care

docs.abstract: Accountable care organizations, collections of medical providers who band together under one business umbrella and are paid to care for a group of patients rather than being reimbursed for specific medical services, are gaining momentum in part because of the Affordable Care Act; ACOs have a powerful incentive to provide forward-looking and high-quality care, because they are allowed to keep and divide savings when patients remain healthy.
docs.snippet: Accountable care organizations, a new kind of health care practice, are gaining momentum in part because of the Affordable Care Act signed into law two years ago.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: A bill in Wisconsin to authorize a hunting season on wolves is opposed by Indian tribes on sacred principle and tradition.

headline.seo: Science, Faith and Politics Clash Over Wolves in Wisconsin
headline.main: Before Wolves May Be Hunted, Science, Faith and Politics Clash
headline.print_headline: Before Wolves May Be Hunted, Science, Faith and Politics Clash

docs.abstract: Bill introduced by the Wisconsin Legislature to authorize a hunting season on wolves has attracted criticism from wildlife biologists and opposition from the Great Lakes Indian Fish and Game Commission, who represent 11 tribes of Ojibwe Native Americans; testimony states that a hunt would violate the religious traditions of the Ojibwe, who hold the wolf as sacred.
docs.snippet: A bill in Wisconsin to authorize a hunting season on wolves is opposed by Indian tribes on sacred principle and tradition.

docs.lead_paragraph: Talk about sleepless nights. Patients taking prescription sleep aids on a regular basis were nearly five times as likely as non-users to die over a period of two and a half years, according to a recent study. Even those prescribed fewer than 20 pills a year were at risk, the researchers found; heavy users also were more likely to develop cancer.

headline.main: The Consumer: Pills' Risks Complicate Long Wait For Sleep

docs.abstract: Daniel F Kripke study in journal BMJ finds that patients taking prescription sleep aids on a regular basis are nearly five times as likely as non-users to die over a period of two and a half years. (M)d
docs.snippet: Talk about sleepless nights.     Patients taking prescription sleep aids on a regular basis were nearly five times as likely as non-users to die over a period of two and a half years, according to a recent study. Even those prescribed fewer than 20...

headline.print_headline: The Consumer: Pills’ Risks Complicate Long Wait For Sleep

docs.abstract: A study finds an unsettling link between the use of sleeping pills and increased risk of death.
docs.snippet: A study finds an unsettling link between the use of sleeping pills and increased risk of death.

docs.lead_paragraph: Considered likely to join the Supreme Court majority either way the case is decided, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. may never encounter a more important ruling.

headline.seo: Health Care Act Offers Roberts a Signature Case
headline.main: Health Care Act Offers Roberts a Signature Case
headline.print_headline: In Health Act, Roberts Given Signature Case

docs.abstract: Chief Justice Roberts will probably lead the Supreme Court for an additional two decades or more, but clashes like the one over the health care law come around only a few times in a century, and he may well complete his service without encountering another case posing such fundamental questions about the structure of American government; on March 26, he will begin presiding over an extraordinary three days of arguments that will determine the fate of President Obama’s sweeping health care law; that debate will shape, if not define, Robert's legacy.
docs.snippet: Considered likely to join the Supreme Court majority either way the case is decided, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. may never encounter a more important ruling.

docs.lead_paragraph: Both liberals and conservatives assault the Constitution in different ways, each with damaging effects on our nation.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by J Harvie Wilkinson III, United States Court of Appeals judge, criticizes both liberals and conservatives for using the Constitution to implement their agendas, resulting in a national jurisprudence whetted by political appetite; maintains that the country faces grave risks from such lack of restraint, but finds hope in the love both sides share for family, community and country.
docs.snippet: Both liberals and conservatives assault the Constitution in different ways, each with damaging effects on our nation.

docs.snippet: A reader responds to an editorial about contraception and abortion rights.

headline.main: Do Electronic Records Cut Health Costs?
headline.print_headline: Do Electronic Records Cut Health Costs?

docs.abstract: Letter from Alan D Aviles, president of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation, comments on the March 6 article on a study that questions whether digital records cut health care costs.
